transcripts.text: Dear Dr.  Arnn, just like millions of other students, I was not prepared for the grief I would feel in missing many of my last moments at college.  In the grand scheme of life, my grief over graduation and a missed month of school is seemingly minuscule, but this grief bears witness to a deep love for Hillsdale College, not just as a degree-granting institution, but as the facilitator of human flourishing through real human interaction.  The physical place of Hillsdale College matters for seniors because this is where we have learned how to actually love our neighbors and to do the right thing at the right time.  In the pursuit of truth, goodness, and beauty, we must not forget the gift of time.  We do not know what tomorrow may bring.  In the end, I understand that this is an unprecedented time in our nation's history.  But even and especially in times of uncertainty and fear, our understanding of human bodies and souls must influence our actions.  I argue that we cannot sacrifice what it means to be a human being right now for a future in which we are not even guaranteed life and breath.  Hillsdale's commencement is a claim about the nature of the human experience.  I trust the college's wisdom and discernment in making this experience as safe as possible, but I ask most fervently that the Class of 2020 would be able to experience commencement as the localized, personal, and profound experience it is meant to be.  Sincerely, Hadiyah Ritchie, Class of 2020.
